Description: The organisation number for the charity. This is the index value for the charity.
The registration number of the registered organisation allocated by the Commission. Note that a main charity and all its linked charities will share the same registered_charity_number.

A number that uniquely identifies the subsidiary or group member associated with a registered charity. Used for user identification purposes where the subsidiary is known by the parent registration number and the subsidiary number. The main parent charity has a linked_charity_number of 0.
The Main Name of the Charity
The type of the charity displayed on the public register of charities. Only the main parent charity will have a value for this field (i.e. linked_charity_number=0).
The charity registration status indicates whether a charity is registered or removed
The date the charity was registered with the Charity Commission.

This is the date the charity was removed from the Register of Charities. This will not necessarily be the same date that the charity ceased to exist or ceased to operate. For non-removed charities the field is NULL.
The current reporting status of the charity
The start date of the latest financial period for which the charity has made a submission.
The end date of the latest financial period for which the charity has made a submission.
The latest income submitted by the charity. This is the total gross income submitted on part A of the annual return submission.
The latest expenditure submitted by a charity. This is the expenditure submitted on part A of the annual return submission.

Number of Volunteers. The trustees' estimate of the number of people who undertook voluntary work in the UK for the charity during the year. The number shown is a head count and not expressed as full-time equivalents. Charities are invited to provide an estimate of volunteer numbers in their Annual Return but are not obliged to do so. Where a number is provided by the charity, including zero, that number is displayed.

Indicates whether the financial data on this line relates to the latest financial data submitted by the charity. (True or False)
A field to aid ordering of the financial data for each charity. (1=Most recent data in the table, 5=Least recent data in the table)
The annual return cycle to which the submission details relate.
The start date of the financial period which is detailed for the charity.

The date the annual return was received for the financial period which is detailed for the charity.
Income from donations and legacies as entered on the Annual Return form for the financial period detailed.
Income received as fees or grants specifically for goods and services supplied by the charity to meet the needs of its beneficiaries for the financial period detailed.
Income from other trading activity as entered on the Annual Return form for the financial period detailed.

Income from investments including dividends, interest and rents but excluding changes (realised and unrealised gains) in the capital value of the investment portfolio for the financial period detailed.

Other income. This category includes gains on the disposal of own use assets (i.e. fixed assets not held as investments), but otherwise is only used exceptionally for very unusual transactions that cannot be accounted for in the categories above for the financial period detailed.
Total income including endowments for the financial period detailed.
Income from legacies as entered on the Annual Return form for the financial period detailed.
Income from endowments as entered on the Annual Return form for the financial period detailed.

Costs associated with providing goods and services to the public, where the main motive is to raise funds for the charity rather than providing goods or services to meet the needs of its beneficiaries for the financial period detailed. (eg charity shops, fundraising dinners etc.).
Costs incurred by the charity in supplying goods or services to meet the needs of its beneficiaries. Grants made to meet the needs of the charity's beneficiaries for the financial period detailed.
Other expenditure for the financial period detailed. This category is only used very exceptionally for items that don't fit within one of the categories above.
Total expenditure for the financial period detailed on the Part B of the annual return.
Expenditure managing investments for the financial period detailed.
Any grants that the charity has awarded to other institutions to further their charitable work.
Costs associated with running the charity itself for the financial period. (e.g. costs of trustee meetings, internal and external audit costs and legal advice relating to governance matters).

Support costs should be allocated across activities and are those costs which, while necessary to deliver an activity, do not themselves produce the activity.  They include the central office functions of the charity and are often apportioned to activities.  The amount shown here is the total amount of support costs (for charitable, fundraising and governance activities) included in resources expended.

Depreciation charge for the year can be found in the fixed asset analysis notes to the accounts.  This is the amount of depreciation on tangible fixed assets (including impairment charges, if any), which will be shown as the charge for the year in the tangible fixed asset note to the accounts.
The gain or loss associated with the charity's investments
The gain or loss associated with the charity's pension fund
The gain or loss associated with any revaluation of fixed assets
The gain or loss associated with any other assets

The level of reserves is those unrestricted funds which are freely available for the charity to spend and can be found in the Financial Review in the Trustees Annual Report and will exclude endowments.

Total fixed assets. Fixed assets are those held for continuing use and include tangible fixed assets such as land, buildings, equipment and vehicles, and any investments held on a long-term basis to generate income or gains.
Total own use assets. This is a calculated field. assets_own_use = assets_total_fixed - assets_long_term_investment

Fixed Asset Investment are held for the long term to generate income or gains and may include quoted and unquoted shares, bonds, gilts, common investment funds, investment property and term deposits held as part of an investment portfolio.
This is surplus or deficit in any defined benefit pension scheme operated and represents a potential long-term asset or liability.
The value of any other assets
The value of the total liabilities for the charity. This is a calculated field. assets_total_liabilities = creditors_one_year_total_current + creditors_falling_due_after_one_year
Total Current Assets are a separate class of Total Current Asset and they are held with intention of disposing of them within 12 months.
Total Net assets or liabilities can be found on the Balance Sheet. This is the total of all assets shown less all liabilities. This should be the same as the Total funds of the charity.
Creditors due within one year are the amounts owed to creditors and include loans and overdrafts, trade creditors, accruals and deferred income and they are payable within one year.
These are the amounts owed to creditors payable after more than one year, with provisions for liabilities and charges.

Cash at bank and in hand are a separate class of Total Current Assets.  This amount includes deposits with banks and other financial institutions, which are repayable on demand, but excludes bank overdrafts.
Endowment funds include the amount of all permanent and expendable endowment funds.

Unrestricted funds include the amount of all funds held for the general purposes of the charity.  This will include unrestricted income funds, designated funds, revaluation reserves and any pension reserve.
Restricted funds include the amount of all funds held that must be spent on the purposes of the charity.
Total funds can be found on the Balance Sheet and should be the same as Total net assets/(liabilities).
The number of people that the charity employs
Indicates if the accounts represent only the charity accounts

Consolidated accounts bring together the resources of the charity and the subsidiaries under its control in one statement. These subsidiaries may be non-charitable and to exist for purposes that benefit the parent charity e.g. fund-raising. If set to 1 the accounts are consolidated.
